title: Why can't you divide by zero?

multiple-choice.question: What happens when you divide a number by smaller and smaller numbers?

options.label: A
options.text: The answer gets smaller and smaller.

options.label: C
options.text: The answer gets bigger and bigger.

multiple-choice.question: Why can't we say that 10 divided by zero is equal to infinity?

options.label: A
options.text: Because infinity is not a number.

options.label: B
options.text: Because dividing by zero is not allowed in mathematics.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the answer tends towards infinity, but is not exactly infinity.

options.label: D
options.text: Because zero has no multiplicative inverse.

multiple-choice.question: What is the multiplicative inverse of a number?

options.label: A
options.text: A number that, when multiplied by the original number, gives zero.

options.label: B
options.text: A number that, when multiplied by the original number, gives one.

options.label: C
options.text: A number that, when multiplied by the original number, gives infinity.

options.label: D
options.text: A number that, when multiplied by the original number, gives a negative number.

multiple-choice.question: Why can't we define the multiplicative inverse of zero as one over zero?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it would lead to a contradiction, such as one equals two.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it would make zero equal to infinity.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it would make all numbers equal to zero.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it would make mathematics too complicated.

options.label: D

options.text: To command a century of soldiers

multiple-choice.question: What was the viaticum that Servius received when he enlisted as a legionary?
